subject: Re: [junit] JUnit4, annotations and inheritance
msgSnippet: Nikunj, Thanks for reporting that.  What you re seeing is a result of how JUnit is written--once a method is marked @Test, no subclass may take that @Test
messageBody:
Nikunj,

Thanks for reporting that. What you're seeing is a result of how JUnit is
written--once a method is marked @Test, no subclass may take that @Test
status away. However, I can't claim that we ever explicitly considered this
case.

Just to be sure I understand what you're trying to do--it looks like you'd
like to create a subclass of BaseCalculatorTest, and ignore or "de-testify"
the addTest method in that subclass--I assume because that method defines a
contract that the subclass for some reason does not (yet) follow. Is that
right?

I'd probably achieve that by defining

class ScientificCalculator {

@Test public void addTest(){
// nothing to see here--add is correct by inspection
}
}

until such time as the appropriate definition of
ScientificCalculator.addTest becomes clear.

To the larger questions, I don't have a clear intuition. JUnit community
activate! What is your expected behavior of ScientificCalculator, as Nikunj
has written below? Run as a Test, Run Ignored, don't run at all, or flag as
a configuration error?

David Saff

On 4/7/07, Nikunj Manocha <manochanikunj@...> wrote:
>
> Hi All,
>
> I am using JUnit 4. I noticed an intersting behavior:
>
> Have two classes:
>
> ========================
> public class BaseCalculatorTest {
>
> @Test
> public void addTest(){
> System.out.println("coming into BaseCalculatorTest class");
> BaseCalculator bc = new BaseCalculator();
> bc.add(1);
> Assert.assertEquals(bc.getResult(),1);
> }
>
> @Test
> public void addTest2(){
> System.out.println("coming into BaseCalculatorTest addTest2 class");
> BaseCalculator bc = new BaseCalculator();
> bc.add(1);
> Assert.assertEquals(bc.getResult(),1);
> }
> }
> ===============
>
> and
>
> ==================
> public class ScientificCalculator extends BaseCalculatorTest {
>
> @Ignore
> public void addTest(){
> System.out.println("coming into ScientificCalculator class");
> BaseCalculator bc = new BaseCalculator();
> bc.add(1);
> Assert.assertEquals(bc.getResult(),1);
> }
> }
> ============================
>
> The Output when run the JUnit tests:
>
> C:\Documents and
> Settings\nmanocha\IdeaProjects\JUnit4Test\classes\production\src>java
>
> -classpath ..\..\..\src\lib\junit4.3\j
> e com.oracle.nm.calculator.BaseCalculatorTest
> com.oracle.nm.calculator.ScientificCalculator
> JUnit version 4.3
> .coming into BaseCalculatorTest class
> .coming into BaseCalculatorTest addTest2 class
> .coming into ScientificCalculator class
> .coming into BaseCalculatorTest addTest2 class
>
> Time: 0.01
>
> OK (4 tests)
>
> ================================
>
> Interesting behavior is I was expecting not to be seeing "coming
> into
> ScientificCalculator class" line in the output for two reasons:
> 1. I haven't put the annotation @Test in front of the
> ScientificCalculator's
> addTest method. And annotation behavior is not inherited for method
> types.
> 2. I explicitly put the @Ignore annotation in front of the
> ScientificCalculator's addTest method. This annotation should have
> made
> JUnit runner ignore this method. Still the method is being called.
>
> Can someone explain why this is happening?
>
> Thanks.
>
> Regards,
> Nikunj
